title: Alex Bregman to Cubs and a Bears playoff win. What a night for Chicago sports.
description: What a night in Chicago: the Bears won their first playoff game in 15 years and the Cubs made their biggest free-agent splash in a decade.
fullText:
Simply, it was the greatest sports evening in Chicago since 2016.

While the Chicago Bears were making arguably the greatest comeback in franchise history against the Green Bay Packers on Saturday night in the playoffs, the Chicago Cubs were making their biggest free-agent splash in a decade with a five-year, $175 million agreement with infielder Alex Bregman.

‚ÄúBig night for Chicago,‚Äô‚Äô Scott Boras, Bregman‚Äôs agent, said in a text to USA TODAY Sports.

So, while the Bears were coming back from a 21-3 halftime deficit to win 31-27, Boras and the Cubs were actually in the middle of negotiations?

‚ÄúBears game?‚Äô‚Äô Boras texted USA TODAY Sports. ‚ÄúI was packing the green in for Breggy with the Cubs.‚Äô‚Äô

The Cubs, who tried to sign Bregman a year ago to a four-year, $115 million deal, got their man and stole him away from the Boston Red Sox with the richest salary in Cubs‚Äô history.

And after listening to critics all winter, saying that they haven‚Äôt made enough moves or spent enough money to make themselves World Series contenders ‚àí or at least better than the Milwaukee Brewers in the NL Central ‚àí they shelled out the big cash after acquiring Miami Marlins starter Edward Cabrera just three days ago.

Just like that, the Cubs have got folks in Chicago believing it could be 2016 all over again, the year they won their first World Series since 1908.

Certainly, Bregman, 31, is a huge winner. He opted out of the $80 million owed to him the next two years by the Boston Red Sox, and spun it into a franchise-record $35-million-a-year deal with a full no-trade clause and no opt-outs. The only Cubs‚Äô contracts bigger in total value is Jason Heyward‚Äôs eight-year, $184 million contract and shortstop Dansby Swanson‚Äôs seven-year, $177 million contract.

Bregman, who turns 32 in March, will now earn $215 million over six years.

Just like that, the Cubs could be a giant in the NL. They now have a wealth of depth in their infield in which they could either slide Matt Shaw to second base and trade Nico Hoerner or make Shaw a super utility player and keep Hoerner for one more year before he hits free agency.

No matter, the Cubs feel as if they‚Äôre set, and love Bregman‚Äôs leadership skills, as he has been in the playoffs every full year of his 10-year career.

This is why the Red Sox badly wanted to bring him back and were runner-up in the negotiations. The Arizona Diamondbacks also had interest in Bregman, but once they decided to retain All-Star second baseman Ketel Marte, they dropped out of the Bregman sweepstakes, leaving the Cubs and Red Sox as the two finalists.

Bregman, who hit .273 with an .821 OPS with 18 homers and 28 doubles last season, is the biggest free agent to sign this winter. Considering he‚Äôs two years older than Cody Bellinger, it perhaps illustrates why Bellinger has not accepted the Yankees‚Äô five-year offer in excess of $150 million.

Bregman‚Äôs signing now leaves the Red Sox badly needing Bo Bichette, who also is being courted by the Philadelphia Phillies and Toronto Blue Jays. Bichette has a zoom call meeting Monday with the Phillies.

The Cubs couldn‚Äôt care less what happens next. They believe they‚Äôre set now. They‚Äôre convinced they can win their first NL Central title in a full season since 2017.

And, hey, with the Cubs‚Äô convention scheduled this upcoming weekend, they not only plan to celebrate the 10-year anniversary of their World Series, but believe it could be a prelude to an October to remember in 2026.

What a night in Chicago, with the Bears winning at Solider Fielder and the Cubs celebrating in their offices at Wrigley Field.

Who would have imagined a brutally cold, blustery evening in Chicago could feel so beautiful?

Follow Nightengale on X: @Bnightengale

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Alex Bregman signing with Cubs and Bears win make great Chicago night

title: Chiefs legend Dustin Colquitt named to Missouri Sports Hall of Fame
description: Kansas City Chiefs legend Dustin Colquitt named to the Missouri Sports Hall of Fame | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs' legends continue to receive their praise well after their playing days have ended. The latest retired Chiefs star to be honored is long-time punter Dustin Colquitt, who was recently named to the Missouri Sports Hall of Fame class of 2026.

Colquitt, who will be enshrined on February 1st in Springfield, played the most games in franchise history and was a two-time Pro Bowler for Kansas City. He was a member of the Kansas City Super Bowl LIV championship team and recently officially retired with the franchise.

The former Tennessee Volunteer was selected by the Chiefs in the third round of the 2005 NFL Draft after his illustrious collegiate career. He spent 14 seasons in Kansas City before joining various teams in the final stretch of his career.

For 15 seasons, Colquitt experienced the franchise's highs and lows. In 238 regular-season games with the Chiefs, Colquitt tallied 1,167 punts and an impressive 477 inside the 20.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs legend Dustin Colquitt named to Missouri Sports Hall of Fame

title: 'The goal of the game?' A sportswriter dives into youth sports mania
description: Former New York Times writer Harvey Araton's novel reveals a raucous life of a youth athlete, and lessons we can all learn from it.
fullText:
It‚Äôs a statement but also a question we can ask ourselves as sports parents.

It‚Äôs driven into our kids very early, often by us.

Or is it to just enjoy the experience?

‚ÄúDad, according to Mom, asked the parents in our group not to worry about how good we were, or weren‚Äôt,‚Äù writes author Harvey Araton, through the eyes of a kid named ‚ÄúZ,‚Äù in a new middle-grade novel.

Z‚Äôs dad was the coach of the boy‚Äôs first soccer team. It‚Äôs a neighborhood collection of grade school buddies. Dad didn‚Äôt just roll out the ball, though. He orchestrated drills that mimicked game situations that gave everyone a shot at the action.

‚ÄúYou scrimmage too much, and the same kids, the stronger players, will dominate the ball, and then how do the other kids get better?‚Äù Z overhears his dad telling his mom early in the book.

Everyone notices, in fiction and reality, when others don‚Äôt have this growth mentality.

Z and his teammates hear opposing parents scream for blood, or at least a foul, when his team, once a doormat, incrementally starts to get better and begins to dominate.

The kids of manic youth sports parents, one of whom Araton admits to once being himself, is whom he wants to reach. The veteran sportswriter, most recently with The New York Times for 25 years, covered the Danny Almonte age scandal at the 2001 Little League World Series, and the ensuing escalation¬†of Little League World Series coverage into American living rooms.

He has pondered or written about (or both) kids choosing between club and high school soccer and early sports specialization.

He also played the role of sports dad to two now-grown sons (36 and 32).

‚ÄúKids learn playing sports,‚Äù Araton tells USA TODAY Sports. ‚ÄúI think there's a joy in that. I just feel, especially at these early years, it's becoming infected with this ambition that there could be a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow and I think too many parents become obsessed with turning their children into potential cash machines.‚Äù

Araton launched the book last week with a signing at his local bookstore in Montclair, New Jersey. He made sure to also include a panel discussion about youth sports. He spoke with us about how his novel imitates the raucous life America lives within it, and the lessons he has gleaned from it.

YOUTH SPORTS SURVIVAL GUIDE:¬†Pre-order Coach Steve's upcoming book for young athletes and their parents

Araton is from Staten Island, which he describes as New York City‚Äôs last developed borough. It still has large swaths of parks and fields, where his story is set.

He had grown up on the basketball courts near his public housing development. The free play felt natural as it took him to the local Jewish community center and high school. He eventually played at a health club in Brooklyn as an adult and even worked in Madison Square Garden, where he covered the Knicks, the team he had idolized as a kid.

His competitive juices carried him into fatherhood when his older son, Alex, was in first grade and had the option of going out for a travel team. It‚Äôs a decision many of us have faced.

‚ÄúI remember asking him if he wanted to try out,‚Äù Araton says. ‚ÄúAnd he was kind of a naturally cautious kid and said, ‚ÄòNot really,‚Äô and I remember being disappointed, a little deflated. Maybe I already was thinking, ‚ÄòIf he doesn't go into this next level, he'll fall behind and never catch up, (and) there will go any chance of playing in high school.‚Äô I mean, I could look at my kids, look at their size even at that age and know that they weren't likely to be D1 college athletes.

‚ÄúBut I remember being disappointed and over the next couple of weeks, I came up with five or six different ways to pose the same question. Well, Nick's trying out, you sure you don't want (to)? And he kept saying no. And then the last time that I asked, he said, ‚ÄòNo, dad.‚Äô And then he looked at me and said, ‚ÄòBut if I don't play travel, can I still play in the town league?‚Äô

‚ÄúAnd I remember feeling this sensation of shame because I realized in that moment that I was projecting my own ambitions and my own sports values onto this 6-year-old kid. And all he wanted to do at that point in his life was just run around and play with a bunch of kids he knew and maybe take one or two things out of any game and feel good about himself and look forward to the snacks.‚Äù

The book‚Äôs central character, who tells the story in the first person, is a combination of Araton‚Äôs two sons. Charly, Alex‚Äôs younger brother, was 4-foot-11 when he entered high school but played on the basketball team for four years.

Z is left-footed with really good field vision like Alex and he‚Äôs small and feisty like Charly was. It doesn‚Äôt seem to bother Z when his young team is losing because he knows he will celebrate the things they all did well, or at least enjoyed, at Big Mitch‚Äôs restaurant afterward.

Big Mitch is the father of his friend and teammate, Lloyd.

‚ÄúYou only let in, like, seven or eight goals on an undefeated travel team,‚Äù he tells Lloyd, the team‚Äôs goalie, in the book. ‚ÄúDo you think a kid who was out of shape could do that?‚Äù

Z becomes less comfortable when sports becomes more and more competitive. His father has a horrific accident and the team eventually gets a coach from England, who adopts a similar skills-first mindset with the kids. Kevin, the coach, who has also had a traumatic experience with his father, takes Z under his wing.

As the boys and girls on the team continue to rise in competition level, and travel further and further away from Staten Island, Z gets a much more transactional coach.

He feels himself immersed in a world over which he has less and less control, similar to the experiences Araton observed and felt as a soccer dad.

‚ÄúThe reason why I chose soccer is because I probably was most closely involved with that, whether it was as coaching them in the early grades or just being at the games and kind of like, living for it a little bit,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI understand why parents are so heavily involved. After a week of work you really look forward to the experience of the games. It's like an adrenaline rush but also I think, it created a whole social network with the parents of their teammates and friends and everything. So I get the temptation, and the seductiveness, of it all, but (it) all got completely out of control, as well.‚Äù

Youth sports 'crisis':¬†Congress addresses big business in youth sports. Can we fix it?

While Araton was growing up on Staten Island, the borough‚Äôs Mid-Island Little League won it all in Williamsport. Years later, as a sportswriter, Araton caught up with Danny Yaccarino, who came within one strike of a perfect game during that 1964 Little League World Series against Monterrey, Mexico.

He wrote a column, (‚ÄòAfter Perfection at the Age of 12, What's Next?‚Äô) detailing how Yaccarino became a very good high school pitcher and reached the Baltimore Orioles organization and yet, he was always haunted by the feeling of coming so close to near-perfection as a Little Leaguer and not getting it.

‚ÄúNot only did he get a lot of bench jockeying and all that stuff throughout his career, but he also put incredible pressure on himself,‚Äù Araton says. ‚ÄúHe turned out to be a minor league pitcher and he never went very far. But he told me that he finished his career feeling like an abject failure.‚Äù

Z feels an emptiness, too, at the climax of the book. It's a feeling that can be induced by us.

"Parents, being vulnerable, and easily manipulated into spending vast sums of money, (wind) up treating their children like they are speculating on a stock, an investment," Araton says. "They're not stocks that will pay off at 8 or 9 or 10 years; they're developing human beings."

‚ÄúZ, we‚Äôre running behind,‚Äù his mother yells upstairs, trying to get him moving for his U-13 fall season-opening game. She‚Äôs now the team‚Äôs driven parent-manager.

‚ÄúThe construction of this story is really about Z coming to an understanding of what role sports should play in his life,‚Äù Araton says. ‚ÄúAnd when I say that, I mean, at that particular time, kids are always subject to change. He's at a point in his life where he's experienced family trauma, and, when he looks around, he doesn't see the friends who he loves, the kids that he grew up playing with. He sees a lot of strange kids. And that's not what he wants. More than playing at an elite level, he wants to play with kids who know him, who know what he's gone through.

‚ÄúHe realizes that he still loves the game, but will only play it under his terms.‚Äù

Isn‚Äôt that what we all want? What about our kids, too?

‚ÄúYou could offer them the higher-level stuff,‚Äù Araton says, ‚Äúbut if it's being forced upon them, and if you're calling up to their bedroom every time there's practice, then it's clear that they don't really want to do it.

‚ÄúI wouldn't deny an exceptional child that kind of pathway any more than you would, say, if you had a child who (was) a mathematical genius or a classical violinist, you would want them to have the best teachers to best capitalize on their special talent. But the temptation is so great because sports is the most visible thing in the community. ‚Ä¶

"It'll become pretty obvious to a parent if they have someone special. But this whole notion that they can create one by spending significant sums of money, I think it's really overstated.‚Äù

Araton points to another interview he did, with Yael Averbuch, the general manager of the New Jersey/New York Gotham FC of the National Women's Soccer League (NWSL). She played for an exclusive club team in high school, won two national championships playing for the University of North Carolina and was drafted professionally.

Her mother said she never had to yell upstairs for practice. Yael was the one yelling to them.

Araton‚Äôs sons, like Z, had to figure out where sports fit into their lives. It worked out for them, too.

Alex, who played high school soccer, is a special education teacher and Charly, the high school basketball player (who has grown to about 5-foot-9 today), works in marketing strategies for a fashion brand. He still plays in men‚Äôs leagues.

Araton says those middle-grade age groups ‚Äì 8 to 12, give or take ‚Äì are the ages where people know the least amount about who their children are as athletes.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be disappointed if at the age of 8, they are not willing to do all this stuff and make all that sacrifice,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThey might be ready when they're 11. Kids do things on their own time schedules. So just accept who they are and let them experience sports in the way they want to. They‚Äôll enjoy it more and get more out of it.

‚ÄúIf they're not playing for the idea of feeling good about themselves, about learning to be a coachable kid, and be a good teammate, to play with kids from all different backgrounds and develop their skills at the fundamental level at the age of 7, 8, 9, 10,‚Äù Araton says, ‚Äúthen they're playing for the wrong reasons.

‚ÄúEach shall develop at their own rate. I just think that parents have to chill and let the kids experience it for themselves.‚Äù

Borelli, aka Coach Steve,¬†has been an¬†editor and writer with USA TODAY since 1999. He spent 10 years coaching his two sons‚Äô baseball and basketball teams. He and his wife, Colleen, are now sports parents for two high schoolers. His Coach Steve column is posted weekly.¬†For his past columns, click here.

Got a question for Coach Steve you want answered in a column? Email him at¬†sborelli@usatoday.com

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: 'The goal of the game?' It's a question sports parents can ask

title: College enforcement group voices 'serious concerns' with spiraling transfer portal
description: A transfer portal spiraling out of control prompted the new regulatory body for college sports to issue a memo to athletic directors Friday night saying it has ‚Äúserious concerns‚Äù about some of the multimillion-dollar contracts being offered to players.  The ‚Äúreminder‚Äù from the College Sports Commission came out about an hour before kickoff of the semifinal between Indiana and Oregon in a College Football Playoff that has shared headlines with news of players signing seven-figure deals to move or, in some cases, stay where they are.  The CSC reminded the ADs that, according to the rules, third-party deals to use players' name, image and likeness ‚Äúare evaluated at the time of entry in NIL Go, not before, and each deal is evaluated on its own merits.‚Äù
fullText:
A transfer portal spiraling out of control prompted the new regulatory body for college sports to issue a memo to athletic directors Friday night saying it has ‚Äúserious concerns‚Äù about some of the multimillion-dollar contracts being offered to players.

The ‚Äúreminder‚Äù from the College Sports Commission came out about an hour before kickoff of the semifinal between Indiana and Oregon in a College Football Playoff that has shared headlines with news of players signing seven-figure deals to move or, in some cases, stay where they are.

The CSC reminded the ADs that, according to the rules, third-party deals to use players' name, image and likeness ‚Äúare evaluated at the time of entry in NIL Go, not before, and each deal is evaluated on its own merits.‚Äù

"Without prejudging any particular deal, the CSC has serious concerns about some of the deal terms being contemplated and the consequences of those deals for the parties involved," the memo said.

Under terms of the House settlement that dictated the rules for NIL payments, schools can share revenue with their players directly from a pool of $20.5 million. Third-party deals, often arranged by businesses created to back the schools, are being used as workarounds this so-called salary cap.

The CSC, through its NIL Go portal, is supposed to evaluate those deals to make sure they are for a valid business purpose and fall within a fair range of compensation for the services being provided.

The CSC did not list examples of unapproved contracts, but college football has seen its share of seven-figure deals luring players to new schools since the transfer portal opened on Jan. 2.

One high-profile case involved Washington quarterback Demond Williams Jr., who initially sought to enter the transfer portal and turn his back on a reported deal worth $4 million with the Huskies. Legal threats ensued and Williams changed course and stayed at Washington.

"Making promises of third-party NIL money now and figuring out how to honor those promises later leaves student-athletes vulnerable to deals not being cleared, promises not being able to be kept, and eligibility being placed at risk," the CSC letter said.

The commission listed two rules about contracts it evaluates, some of which have been termed ‚Äúagency agreement‚Äù or ‚Äúservices agreement‚Äù in what look like attempts to bypass the rules.

‚Äî"The label on the contract does not change the analysis; if an entity is agreeing to pay a student-athlete for their NIL, the agreement must be reported to NIL Go within the reporting deadline."

‚Äî"An NIL agreement or payment with an associated entity or individual ... must include direct activation of the student-athlete‚Äôs NIL rights." This is a reference to the practice of ‚Äúwarehousing‚Äù NIL rights by paying first, then deciding how to use them later.

title: Four arrested for $100k theft at California sports card shop
description: Pok√©mon and sports cards were stolen from LA Sports Cards
fullText:
Four men have been arrested in connection with the theft of $100,000 in collectibles at a sports card store in Burbank, California, the Burbank Police Department announced Thursday.

Brian Chavez, 22, of Los Angeles, Jeremy Lopez, 22, of Los Angeles, Marco Barrongil, 26, of North Hollywood, and Elijah Garcia, 27, of Compton, have been arrested and booked for burglary.

Formal charges are pending review.

According to police reports, the burglary occurred at 2 a.m. on Dec. 2 at LA Sports Cards. Police found ‚Äúevidence of forced entry at the front of the business‚Äù with the inside of the store damaged.

Pok√©mon cards, sports cards and other collectibles, with an estimated value of approximately $100,000, were among the items stolen.

Search warrants were served Dec. 18 and Jan. 8 at four separate locations. Evidence was found linking the suspects to the burglary, according to police.

Want more stories like this? 

Ben Burrows is a reporter and editor for cllct, the premier company for collectible culture. He was previously the collectibles editor at Sports Illustrated. You can follow him on X and Instagram @benmburrows.

title: USC Tight End Transfer Walker Lyons Commits to BYU
description: BYU added its likely starting tight end to next season‚Äôs team as USC transfer Walker Lyons has signed with BYU, according to multiple reports. Lyons is listed as a 4-star transfer by 247 Sports. Walker is the older brother of BYU QB commit Ryder Lyons. He heavily considered BYU before his mission but ultimately committed [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
BYU added its likely starting tight end to next season‚Äôs team as USC transfer Walker Lyons has signed with BYU, according to multiple reports. Lyons is listed as a 4-star transfer by 247 Sports.

BREAKING: USC transfer TE Walker Lyons has signed with BYU, @Hayesfawcett3 and @PeteNakos reportüòºhttps://t.co/dfiddkSs5y pic.twitter.com/0QmMsaqC0A

‚Äî Transfer Portal (@TransferPortal) January 9, 2026

BYU has signed USC tight end transfer Walker Lyons, @chris_hummer and I have learned.

Was a Class of 2023 top-115 overall recruit. Had 20 catches and two touchdowns for the Trojans this season. pic.twitter.com/6dSUDVnhoT

‚Äî Matt Zenitz (@mzenitz) January 9, 2026

Walker is the older brother of BYU QB commit Ryder Lyons. He heavily considered BYU before his mission but ultimately committed to the Trojans. Listed at 6-foot-4 and 245 pounds, Walker was USC‚Äôs fifth leading receiver. He finished the season with 20 receptions, 223 receiving yards, and 2 TDs. He had 4 catches for 39 yards at Illinois and 2 catches for 42 yards versus Michigan.

BYU must replace starting tight end Carsen Ryan and Lyons will likely fill that role. He is a big body who has good receiving skills and should see his production see a big uptick now that he has a clear path to be tight end #1. Aaron Roderick has proven that he will use skilled tight ends. Carsen Ryan was BYU‚Äôs third leading receiver this season, finishing with 45 receptions, 620 yards, and 3 TDs. Lyons has the same ability to make a similar impact.

Lyons will be a junior this upcoming season and should make a big impact both of his seasons in Provo.

You can watch some highlights below.

I see you Walker Lyons!

Initial contact at the 15-yard line. Disengagement not until out of bounds at the 2-yard line. pic.twitter.com/2cZ6gtUljW

‚Äî Shotgun Spratling (@ShotgunSpr) September 3, 2025

Walker Lyons gets his first career touchdown üôå@uscfb up, 31-13.

üì∫: FS1 pic.twitter.com/0iGmmDNWG1

‚Äî Big Ten Football (@B1Gfootball) September 7, 2025

We‚Äôve talked a lot about Lake McRee and Walker Lyons as a pass catchers this season but the two tight ends were phenomenal blockers vs. Nebraska. 

Lyons delivers a big block to help pave a lane for King Miller and McRee buries a defender. #USC pic.twitter.com/TFUCYLTIZ5

‚Äî Kendell Hollowell (@KHollowell_) November 2, 2025

title: TST Today: Rams on the Practice Field, Lakers Win Streak Ends, Trae Young Traded
description: Welcome to The Sporting Tribune Podcast Network and a new episode of The Sporting Tribune Today, our every-weekday show on sports in Southern California, Las Vegas and Hawaii.
fullText:
Welcome to The Sporting Tribune Podcast Network and a new episode of The Sporting Tribune Today, our every-weekday show on sports in Southern California, Las Vegas and Hawaii. Hosted by Grant Mona, today‚Äôs episode delivers voices from the field and the locker room as two L.A. teams face very different moments.

Segment One ‚Äî Rams Practice Availability:Grant opens with insight from¬†Matthew Stafford,¬†Sean McVay, and¬†Davante Adams¬†speaking at Rams practice. The trio discusses preparation, chemistry, and expectations as the Rams lock in for the next stretch of games. McVay details what he‚Äôs emphasizing in practice, Stafford talks execution and rhythm, and Adams shares his perspective on settling into the offense and raising the standard.

Segment Two ‚Äî Lakers Postgame After Loss to the Spurs:In the second segment, Grant shifts to the Lakers‚Äô locker room following their loss to the San Antonio Spurs. Hear from JJ Redick, Luka Donƒçiƒá, and Jaxson Hayes as they break down what went wrong, missed opportunities, and what the team needs to clean up moving forward after a frustrating night.

The podcast can be heard every day on Apple, Google, Spotify, iHeart Radio, TuneIn and wherever you get your podcast and every weekday on the radio on KIRN 670 AM and 95.5 FMHD3 in Southern California, 98.5 The Bet in Las Vegas and the Hawaii Sports Radio Network 95.1 FM and 760 AM in Hawaii.

title: Manfred says MLB prepared to produce and distribute local broadcasts for FanDuel network teams
description: Major League Baseball is prepared to produce and distribute local broadcasts for teams whose telecasts are uncertain this season because of the financial problems of the FanDuel Sports Network regional networks.  Main Street Sports Group, which operates the FanDuel networks, did not make its December payment to the St. Louis Cardinals.  It also carries games of Atlanta, Cincinnati, Detroit, Kansas City, the Los Angeles Angels, Miami, Milwaukee and Tampa Bay along with 13 teams in the NBA and seven in the NHL.
fullText:
NEW YORK (AP) ‚Äî Major League Baseball is prepared to produce and distribute local broadcasts for teams whose telecasts are uncertain this season because of the financial problems of the FanDuel Sports Network regional networks.

Main Street Sports Group, which operates the FanDuel networks, did not make its December payment to the St. Louis Cardinals. It also carries games of Atlanta, Cincinnati, Detroit, Kansas City, the Los Angeles Angels, Miami, Milwaukee and Tampa Bay along with 13 teams in the NBA and seven in the NHL.

‚ÄúNo matter what what happens, whether it‚Äôs Main Street, a third party or MLB media, fans are going to have the games,‚Äù baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said Thursday.

MLB took over broadcasts for San Diego in May 2023 after Diamond Sports Group missed a payment to the Padres and added Arizona that July.

Colorado joined MLB's distribution in 2024, and Cleveland and Minnesota in 2025. Seattle is being added this season and possibly Washington, which is leaving the Mid-Atlantic Sports Network.

Diamond was renamed Main Street Sports Group as it emerged out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings last year and its networks were rebranded as FanDuel.

‚ÄúOur focus, particularly given the point in the calendar, is to maximize the revenue that‚Äôs available to the clubs, whether that‚Äôs MLB Media or third party,‚Äù Manfred said. ‚ÄúThe clubs have control over the timing. They can make a decision to move to MLB Media because of the contractual status now. I think that what's happening right now clubs are evaluating their alternatives. Obviously they‚Äôve made significant payroll commitments already and they‚Äôre evaluating the alternatives to find the best revenue source for the year and the best outlet in terms of providing quality broadcasts to their fans.‚Äù

Manfred said local media provides more than 20% of industry revenue.

MLB and the players' association for 2024 allowed discretionary fund distributions of up to $15 million each to teams whose local media revenue had declined since 2022 or 2023, but they did not reach a similar agreement for 2025.

‚ÄúWe are not providing financial assistance right now,‚Äù Manfred said.

He spoke at a news conference to announce an initiative with Foster Love that envisions 250,000 volunteer hours to mark the 250th anniversary of the United States. At the news conference, MLB staff assembled duffel bags with goods for foster care children.

AP MLB: https://apnews.com/hub/MLB

title: SI The Party presented by DraftKings returns to Cow Palace during Super Bowl weekend
description: SAN FRANCISCO ‚Äî Sports Illustrated will bring back one of Super Bowl weekend‚Äôs signature parties in 2026, announcing Wednesday that SI The Party Presented by DraftKings will take over San Francisco‚Äôs historic Cow Palace on Saturday, Feb.
fullText:
SAN FRANCISCO ‚Äî Sports Illustrated will bring back one of Super Bowl weekend‚Äôs signature parties in 2026, announcing Wednesday that SI The Party Presented by DraftKings will take over San Francisco‚Äôs historic Cow Palace on Saturday, Feb. 7.

Produced by Authentic Live and Medium Rare, the event has become a premier off-field destination where league owners, franchise executives, athletes, celebrities and fans converge for a high-energy, all-inclusive nightlife experience outside the game itself.

The 2026 edition will feature headline performances from The Chainsmokers, Ludacris, DJ Irie and rising DJ-producer Xandra, blending electronic, hip-hop and open-format DJ sets into a genre-spanning celebration. Organizers teased additional surprise guests and moments throughout the night.

Premium all-inclusive tickets, VIP access and table packages will go on sale Thursday, Jan. 8 at 10 a.m. PT, with early entry available to fans who pre-register at sitheparty.com for first access. SI said VIP ticketholders will also receive entry to the Lexus LX VIP Lounge inside the venue.

Sports Illustrated described the party as an extension of its long-running identity at the crossroads of sports, entertainment and culture.

‚ÄúFrom the beginning, SI The Party has been an extension of Sports Illustrated‚Äôs legacy at the intersection of sports, entertainment and culture,‚Äù the company said in its announcement.

Past guest lists have included a who‚Äôs who of star power, from Jeff Bezos and Leonardo DiCaprio to Kim Kardashian, Justin Bieber, Alex Rodriguez and Super Bowl champions like Patrick Mahomes.

The 2026 event will feature cross-brand activations from sponsors including Anheuser-Busch, Shaq-A-Licious XL Gummies, Velocity Black, Verizon, CELSIUS, Verizon, Velocity Black, Nine West, Thomasville, Verizon, Velocity Black, CELSIUS, and others.

DraftKings, the presenting sponsor and exclusive gaming operator for the event, will host a DraftKings Lounge at the center of the party, offering curated hospitality and custom brand moments.

‚ÄúThis is one of the most anticipated weekends in sports, and SI The Party sets the stage for the celebration,‚Äù DraftKings Chief Customer Officer Shawn Henley said. ‚ÄúThe DraftKings Lounge will give fans and VIP guests an unforgettable way to engage with one of the biggest events of the year.‚Äù

Henley added that Verizon customers will have opportunities to claim exclusive tickets through Verizon Access in the My Verizon app, along with expedited entry via a dedicated fast lane.

Matt Goldstein, EVP of Authentic Live, said the party‚Äôs goal has always been to deliver an insider-level experience, even at massive scale.

‚ÄúAcross Big Game Weekend and other tentpole moments on the world‚Äôs biggest sporting stages, our vision with SI The Party has always been to deliver hospitality that feels intimate and insider,‚Äù Goldstein said.

Lexus, the event‚Äôs official vehicle sponsor, will showcase its Lexus LX model with a custom-built photo moment as guests transition from the red carpet to the main room inside the Cow Palace.

Authentic Live and Medium Rare also highlighted an interactive truck experience featuring Shaquille O‚ÄôNeal‚Äôs Shaq-A-Licious XL Gummies, where guests will be able to sample the gummies during the event. SI also confirmed that CELSIUS, the official energy drink sponsor for the fourth consecutive year, will be integrated throughout the event, providing guests with beverage sampling and energy-boost activations.

title: Demond Williams transfer: New information emerges on Washington QB‚Äôs attempt to back out of contract
description: New details have emerged surrounding Demond Williams and his attempt to enter the transfer portal, shedding light on why Washington officials are refusing to process his request. According to Ross Dellenger of Yahoo Sports, Williams recently signed a one-year revenue-sharing agreement with the Huskies worth approximately $4 million. The agreement is a Big Ten‚Äìapproved template [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
New details have emerged surrounding Demond Williams and his attempt to enter the transfer portal, shedding light on why Washington officials are refusing to process his request.

According to Ross Dellenger of Yahoo Sports, Williams recently signed a one-year revenue-sharing agreement with the Huskies worth approximately $4 million. The agreement is a Big Ten‚Äìapproved template used by all conference members and was specifically designed to address scenarios like this.

The contract evidently prohibits Williams from entering the transfer portal once signed, and restricts his NIL rights from being used by another school. He‚Äôs still allowed to pursue outside marketing deals per Dellenger.

As a result, Washington has declined to enter Williams‚Äô name into the portal, which prevents him from holding conversations with other programs. Dellenger reported that Big Ten Conference commissioner Tony Petitti is heavily involved in the matter, along with other league officials.

Additionally, the conference is backing Washington‚Äôs firm stance. Coincidentally, Petitti is in Seattle this week for a memorial service while discussions continue.

Moreover, Washington officials are expected to communicate later Tuesday with Williams‚Äô representatives regarding next steps. The school also suspects Williams has already spoken with other programs and plans to submit any evidence of tampering to both the conference and the NCAA. LSU is believed to be the program most interested in Williams.

Less than a week before announcing his intention to transfer, Williams signed the new deal at Washington, a development first reported by Pete Nakos of On3. Sources emphasized to Nakos that Williams remains under contract and that Washington expects him to be its starting quarterback in 2026 under head coach Jedd Fisch. The Huskies were also prepared to make Williams one of the highest-paid quarterbacks in college football.

The situation mirrors a similar case last year involving Wisconsin Badgers defender Xavier Lucas, who withdrew from Wisconsin and enrolled at Miami Hurricanes without entering the portal.

Wisconsin claimed Lucas was bound by a two-year NIL agreement and pursued legal action, with attorney Darren Heitner representing Lucas. That lawsuit remains ongoing, and Dellenger noted the language in Williams‚Äô deal closely resembles the template used in the Wisconsin case.

Williams is coming off a standout sophomore season, throwing for 3,065 yards and 25 touchdowns while adding 611 rushing yards and six scores. In announcing his intent to transfer Tuesday night, Williams said the decision was made with his future in mind, though Washington appears prepared to enforce the contract he signed just days earlier.

‚Äî On3‚Äôs Nick Schultz contributed to this article.

title: Arc Raiders Tops The Charts While Battlefield 6 Drops In PlayStation's Top Games Of December 2025
description:
Shooters and sports games were quite popular for PlayStation players during the holiday season, with the record-setting Arc Raiders ending its successful first year in the top spot of the PSN charts for December 2025 in the United States and Canada.
Not far from the relatively cheap extraction game are fellow shooters Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 at No. 3 and Grand Theft Auto 5 at No. 5, along with a cavalcade of sports titles that include NBA 2K26 at No. 2, Madden NFL 26 at No.
fullText:
on January 7, 2026 at 8:50AM PST

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Shooters and sports games were quite popular for PlayStation players during the holiday season, with the record-setting Arc Raiders ending its successful first year in the top spot of the PSN charts for December 2025 in the United States and Canada.

Not far from the relatively cheap extraction game are fellow shooters Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 at No. 3 and Grand Theft Auto 5 at No. 5, along with a cavalcade of sports titles that include NBA 2K26 at No. 2, Madden NFL 26 at No. 4, and EA Sports FC 26 at No. 6.

Faltering in the charts, however, is Battlefield 6, though it still remains in a respectable No. 8 spot on December's list. Meanwhile, Marvel Cosmic Invasion, which launched at the beginning of December, is at No. 18, while Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora rides the wave from a new DLC expansion tying into the new Avatar film to land in the No. 14 position.

On the PlayStation 4 side, Red Dead Redemption 2 continues to dominate in both North America and the European Union, while Plants vs. Zombies: Garden Warfare 2 (which is currently available at a steep discount on the PSN store) surprises by shooting up in the No. 3 spot. In the States, four different Five Nights at Freddy's titles take up spots on the PS4 list.

Beat Saber was the most-played PS VR2 game last month, though the game is discontinuing support and online multiplayer this month. Finally, Fortnite ended up as the top free-to-play game in December, likely owing to its annual Winterfest festivities.

Check out the full breakdown of PlayStation's top games for December 2025 in North America and Europe below.

title: Dual Pokemon Card Heists See Over $300,000 Of Rare Collectibles Stolen
description:
This past weekend has seen a new spate of Pok√©mon TCG-related crimes, with over $300,000 worth of rare cards stolen in two seperate incidents in Southern California. In one, thieves broke into a trading card store and smashed display cases, while a second incident saw a collector held up at gunpoint for a briefcase of rare cards.
Trading card store Simi Sportscards in the Simi Valley was the target of a break-in early Sunday morning, KTLA reports, with CCTV footage showing a group of at least five thieves smashing display cases to steal the cards inside. Store owner Jake Miller says the group stole rare sports trading cards and valuable Pok√©mon TCG cards after sawing through the front door. He estimates the break-in will cost the store over $50,000 in repairs, lost merchandise, and security upgrades.

title: Who should Ravens hire to replace John Harbaugh? With Lamar Jackson, Ravens have a luxury their counterparts don't
description: "The jobs this cycle all lack QBs like normal so he's definitely the top QB and offense available for any coach," one NFC exec told Yahoo Sports. An AFC assistant added: "Any scheme fits him."
fullText:
When the Cleveland Browns and Las Vegas Raiders interview head coaches in the coming weeks, they know the most important question they must answer: How will we identify and develop a young quarterback?

When the New York Giants and Tennessee Titans interview head coaches, they, too, know the crux: First-round quarterbacks Jaxson Dart and Cam Ward need molding and development. The quarterback hopeful for each club is in the house. But how will he grow?

Shakeup at the top of the Atlanta Falcons and Arizona Cardinals will similarly require answers on a position with major question marks in 2026 and beyond.

These answers need not all come via offensive head coaches during a hiring cycle riper with defensive candidates than offensive. And in many successful franchises, including the reigning Super Bowl champions, the head coach‚Äôs primary responsibility is not to call offensive plays.

But when teams front young quarterbacks or face questions at quarterback, the pressure to find the offensive panacea sharpens. Coaching searches often skew accordingly.

So the Baltimore Ravens hold a clear advantage.

Because as they announced Tuesday night that 18-year head coach John Harbaugh was ‚Äúrelieved of his duties,‚Äù the Ravens are the lone team currently looking for a head coach that is not simultaneously searching to clarify their answer at quarterback.

Recruiting coaches while two-time MVP Lamar Jackson is under contract is a luxury.

Sure, plenty will argue that just as the Ravens become the most attractive of seven NFL openings and counting, Harbaugh immediately became the most attractive candidate when he hit the market. That doesn‚Äôt mean the decision should be baffling. With a Super Bowl-winning coach and an MVP-winning quarterback, it should not be surprising if each believes he has the answers to future success. And if those answers don‚Äôt align, a time comes for a change.

But as the Ravens look for a coach who will end their 13-year Super Bowl drought, they won‚Äôt need as strong an emphasis on developing a quarterback.

[Get more Ravens news: Baltimore team feed]

That could allow them, should they want, to select the best overall candidate first. Their ceiling will immediately be high.

‚ÄúWe have so much talent on this team, and it's just disappointing that we're not able to be the team that's able to execute and win games when we need to win games,‚Äù fullback Patrick Ricard said this week. ‚ÄúAs long as we have Lamar Jackson, I feel like this team can win a Super Bowl.‚Äù

A minority of coaches and executives across the league will argue that a coach in the Shanahan and McVay systems may prefer a more in-structure passer to build their offense around.

But more often, as the surprise of Harbaugh‚Äôs dismissal hit Tuesday, league voices understood the new pecking order of openings.

‚ÄúThe jobs this cycle all lack QBs like normal so he‚Äôs definitely the top QB and offense available for any coach,‚Äù one NFC executive told Yahoo Sports.

An AFC assistant added of Jackson: ‚ÄúAny scheme fits him.‚Äù

Jackson has shown that in eight seasons since the Ravens selected him with the 32nd pick of the 2018 NFL Draft. He‚Äôs earned four Pro Bowl berths, three All-Pro honors and two MVP awards while winning 76 of 107 regular-season starts.

In aggregate, Jackson has completed 64.8% of his passes for 22,608 yards and 187 passing touchdowns to 56 interceptions. His 102.2 career passer rating and 8.25 air yards per attempt currently hold the all-time career records, per Pro Football Reference.

And those numbers don‚Äôt even include Jackson‚Äôs additional 6,522 yards and 35 touchdowns rushing.

His health has been inconsistent at times, Jackson most recently missing four games and about half of another this season with hamstring and back injuries. But while healthy, he thrived. Consider his Week 18 return from a back injury in Pittsburgh with the AFC North title on the line. While the Ravens lost on a walk-off missed field-goal attempt Sunday night, Jackson completed 11 of 18 passes for 238 yards and three touchdowns.

He activated another level in the fourth quarter, with 50- and 64-yard go-ahead touchdown passes to receiver Zay Flowers. The first came despite two defenders seeming to have Jackson wrapped up. Jackson was unfazed.

Insane sack escape and 50-yard TD from Lamar Jackson. 

Ravens 17, Steelers 13.pic.twitter.com/mgwAU6YIQG

‚Äî Jori Epstein (@JoriEpstein) January 5, 2026

‚ÄúShoot ‚Äî I cut a nose guard loose, and he somehow slipped out of it and threw the ball [50] yards for a touchdown,‚Äù center Tyler Linderbaum said. ‚ÄúThat's the kind of ability he has. So, he‚Äôs fun to play for. [He‚Äôs an] ultra competitor, and any time that ball is snapped to him, and it's in his hands, you know something electrifying can happen.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe most electrifying player there is in this game.‚Äù

As reports of tension between Jackson and Harbaugh built this season, Jackson was asked last Thursday if he had a good relationship with Harbaugh.

‚ÄúYes, I believe so,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where the noise came from. I don‚Äôt know where the noise came from.‚Äù

After the Ravens‚Äô 26-24 loss Sunday, Jackson was asked about Harbaugh again.

Did he want to see Harbaugh as his head coach next season?

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre asking me about next year,‚Äù Jackson said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so caught up in what just happened tonight. I can't focus on that right now, I just told you. Like he asked me, ‚ÄòAre you stunned?‚Äô

‚ÄúI‚Äôm stunned right now, and I'm still trying to process what's going on. I know we lost, but what the ... you know?‚Äù

Sure, the emotions of the season‚Äôs sudden ending were fresh as Jackson‚Äôs Herculean fourth quarter wasn‚Äôt enough to advance to a sixth playoff berth in eight years. But Jackson was not the first player to receive a question about his coach‚Äôs future at season‚Äôs end. He would not have been the first to endorse a leader after a loss, especially one 18 years into his tenure with the organization with a Lombardi Trophy to his name and an AFC championship game berth in partnership with Jackson.

Harbaugh issued his own statement, curiously including a smiley-face emoji as he said goodbye with ‚Äúdisappointment certainly, but more with GRATITUDE & APPRECIATION.‚Äù

Is John Harbaugh the first NFL coach to include a smiley face in his statement about being fired? pic.twitter.com/NhHouUIL0C

‚Äî Jori Epstein (@JoriEpstein) January 6, 2026

The Ravens' coaching search, as team owner Steve Bisciotti said in a statement, begins. Their ability to move quickly on top defensive candidates including the Los Angeles Chargers‚Äô Jesse Minter, Los Angeles Rams‚Äô Chris Shula and Houston Texans‚Äô Matt Burke could prove to be an asset.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a dream backfield to have Lamar and Derrick [Henry] and to play with those guys,‚Äù Ricard said. ‚ÄúI feel like, as long as they're here, this team has a shot ‚Äî no matter who else is playing.‚Äù

title: Unbeatens SF Christian, West Central meet in GOTW
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî The first KELOLAND Sports Game of the Week for the basketball season is a battle of unbeatens as West Central travels to take on reigning Class ‚ÄòA‚Äô state champion Sioux Falls Christian. Coverage begins at 7 p.m.
fullText:
SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî The first KELOLAND Sports Game of the Week for the basketball season is a battle of unbeatens as West Central travels to take on reigning Class ‚ÄòA‚Äô state champion Sioux Falls Christian.

Coverage begins at 7 p.m. Tuesday night on KELOXTRA, KELOLAND.com and KELOLAND+.

Top-ranked SFC is 3-0 and has won 13 straight games dating back to last season. It defeated Lennox by 26 to open the season, then routed Elk Point-Jefferson by 53 and topped Huron 66-61 in its most recent game last Tuesday.

Brant Wassenaar leads the Chargers with 21.3 points and 6.3 rebounds per game. Cooper Goodbary is also averaging double figures with 13 points, five rebounds, 2.6 assists and two steals a night.

The Trojans are ranked No. 2 in Class ‚ÄòA‚Äô and boast a 6-0 record. They won all three of their games last week and are averaging 78 points per game this season. West Central is winning by an average of 38.8 points per game.

Three players are averaging in double figures. Connor Mebius leads the way with 18.5 points a game. Big man Will Kuhl contributes 15.7 points and 6.8 rebounds a night. Hayden Heier chips in 12 points per game.

Sioux Falls Christian has won the last five meetings in the series. West Central‚Äôs last win came back in December 2021.

Play-by-play and commentary will be provided by KELOLAND‚Äôs Grant Sweeter and Ian Sacks.

title: What does Browns firing Kevin Stefanski mean for Shedeur Sanders?
description:
The organization planted seeds of doubt about the Browns‚Äô answer to the most impactful position in sports.
Neither GM Andrew Berry nor team owner Jimmy Haslam endorsed Sanders as their 2026 answer.
fullText:
On a day when the Cleveland Browns knew fans wanted answers and accountability, team brass didn‚Äôt hide the direction the franchise must go.

‚ÄúThe offense, it‚Äôs no secret that‚Äôs where we‚Äôre going to invest most of our resources this offseason,‚Äù general manager Andrew Berry said.

Team owner Jimmy Haslam agreed that ‚Äúwe have a lot of work to do on the roster, particularly on the offensive side of the roster.‚Äù

That neither man crowned any quarterback on their roster as the 2026 leader was telling ‚Äî not because Shedeur Sanders, Dillon Gabriel and Deshaun Watson have no chance, but because it is clear that none of them has a guarantee.

A new head coach will arrive in Cleveland soon, after the Browns fired Kevin Stefanski after six seasons featured a 45-56 (.446) regular-season record.

That coach will have meaningful say on who starts at quarterback for the Browns next season and what will be most highly valued at the position.

[Get more Browns news: Cleveland team feed]

That the Browns will hire an offensive-minded head coach to develop that quarterback is no guarantee: The job will be ‚Äúto make sure that the offense is run and developed well,‚Äù Berry said, ‚Äúas opposed to necessarily having to be the person that directly does it.‚Äù

But losing, particularly in three- and five-win seasons the last two years, cost Stefanski his job. And the Browns know that finding a lasting quarterback answer is the No. 1 factor that will correlate with turning around their win total.

No one is saying aloud that Sanders, Gabriel and Watson cannot be the answer. But the organization planted seeds of doubt Monday about the Browns‚Äô answer to the most impactful position in sports.

Neither Berry nor Haslam endorsed Sanders, their starter to end the season, as their 2026 answer. The next head coach will have a say, and Sanders himself acknowledged that ‚Äúwhen it comes to those grown-up decisions that‚Äôs not me.‚Äù

What the Browns do know, and were willing to say, is that they need an answer quickly.

‚ÄúAt the end of the day, the National Football League is a quarterback league, right?‚Äù seven-time Pro Bowl left guard Joel Bitonio said. ‚ÄúIf you have an elite quarterback in this league, it allows you to be a little bit more sustained in your success. And it's not me saying like, ‚ÄòDo we know if Shedeur or Dillon or Deshaun or Bailey [Zappe], any of these guys is that guy,‚Äô right?

‚ÄúWe have those guys in our locker room. But until you have a guy that can stay healthy and can be on the field and be that guy for your team, it's hard to have that sustained success. ‚Ä¶

‚ÄúUntil you find one that's stable and can lead your team, it's going to be hard to not ride the roller coaster of wins and losses.‚Äù

The Browns do not regret that they evaluated and practiced with four quarterbacks during the offseason and training camp.

Considering depth was not the problem. Missing on a higher ceiling was.

‚ÄúWe believe in competition in every room on the roster, and quarterback‚Äôs no different,‚Äù Berry said. ‚ÄúQuarterback is the most important position in sports. We all know that. And part of the equation with quarterback is the evaluation part. Part of it is the development part as well.‚Äù

The Browns traded away the second overall pick in the 2025 NFL Draft rather than spend a premium pick on quarterback as some expected. Later in the draft, they selected two quarterbacks ‚Äî Gabriel in the third round followed by Sanders in the fifth. It was a curious move. And yet, Berry believes philosophically in expending significant resources at quarterback.

‚ÄúI wouldn't necessarily say draft a quarterback every year, I don't believe it being that,‚Äù Berry told Yahoo Sports last June from minicamp. ‚ÄúBut if you're in position to make a bet on a quarterback that you think can be a quality starter or some level of high-level proficiency, understand that it's not always going to pan out. That's a bet you should be making because you just never know.‚Äù

The philosophy suggests the Browns will not stay put at quarterback this spring, the question of their acquisition more a question of how rather than if. In their 2025 season, the Browns recognized their transitional stage and built up the roster at some positions. But while their defense posted its second top-five unit in three years, the Browns‚Äô offense ranked bottom-five in offense for the second straight season.

A year after ranking last in scoring, the Browns ranked second-to-last this year. In what Berry and Haslam described as a year of roster ‚Äútransition,‚Äù the franchise evaluated its rookies at length.

The Browns won three of Sanders‚Äô seven games compared to one of Gabriel's six, wins often considered the ‚Äúmost important‚Äù quarterback statistic. In traditional quarterback stats, their performance was mixed.

Sanders averaged 193 passing yards per start compared to Gabriel‚Äôs 153, while completing 59.5% of his attempts to Gabriel‚Äôs 58.9%. But Sanders‚Äô 0.8 touchdown-to-interception ratio (seven touchdowns, nine interceptions in seven games) paled in comparison to Gabriel‚Äôs 3.0 (six touchdowns to two interceptions in six games). Sanders‚Äô 72.9 passer rating trailed Gabriel‚Äôs 78.9.

Sanders earned the right to continue starting and warranting evaluation through season‚Äôs end. But with below-league-average metrics, the Browns are not saying right now that he‚Äôs earned the right to start next season.

‚ÄúWe saw a lot of progress with Shedeur this year,‚Äù Berry said. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs both mentally, physically, playing the position. He‚Äôs still very much a work in progress like many rookie quarterbacks are. But I think we saw some really good things in terms of his playmaking, his accuracy, his ability to extend [plays] with his feet. And I think I‚Äôd also give him credit as well as our offensive staff for bringing him along in terms of his pocket management, his situational awareness and things of that nature.

‚ÄúNow that all being said, we‚Äôre going to do our work on the quarterback market. It‚Äôs too important of a position and it‚Äôs something that has to be solidified. I can‚Äôt sit here and tell you today, you know, whether the solution for or the starter in 2026 is internal or external. But it‚Äôs something that we‚Äôre going to work through over the next several weeks. And quite honestly, the new head coach will also have a lot of input into that as well.‚Äù

Perhaps the best thing the Browns can do for their quarterback future is hire the coach they best believe will lead their organization, independent of any single quarterback style.

Berry acknowledged that ‚Äúschemes, they really do come and go.‚Äù An NFC assistant coach whose team helped their quarterback rebound after a coaching change felt no single schematic factor was the answer in their club.

‚ÄúI think they just need to find the best coach possible,‚Äù the assistant told Yahoo Sports. ‚ÄúYou just need to hire the best guy for each job of the organization vs. being predetermined to get a QB guru or whatever you think you need stylistically.

‚ÄúThat way you‚Äôre able to pivot if it turns out [the quarterback] isn‚Äôt the guy, but at least you hired the right coach.‚Äù

This year‚Äôs sophomore quarterback class is evidence of that.

Setting a historic pace, teams selected six quarterbacks in the first 12 picks of the 2024 NFL Draft. Second overall pick Jayden Daniels took the Commanders to the NFC Championship game in his first season under center. This year, three more 2024 quarterbacks have led their teams to a playoff berth.

Selected at first, third and 12th respectively, Caleb Williams, Drake Maye and Bo Nix vary in style and NFL early-career experience. While Nix arrived to an organization with coaching stability, receiving play calls from Super Bowl-winning Sean Payton, his counterparts each entered Year 2 with a new head coach. Their two coaching r√©sum√©s differ vastly, Ben Johnson a first-time head coach who‚Äôs calling offensive plays while Mike Vrabel is a second-time head coach calling plays on neither side of the ball.

And yet, talent evaluators around the league look at each of their stories and see the success stemming from coach at least as much as quarterback. The ‚Äúright‚Äù coach was hired. Neither his quality or quantity of experience determined whether he was the right coach.

Finding Mr. Right will be Berry‚Äôs job in the coming weeks, after which the group will decide how and with whom they want to augment the quarterback room. Doing nothing, while currently on track for a host of 2026 draft picks, including the sixth overall as well as a late first-round selection, would be shocking.

While free agency is always an option, 12 of the 14 starting quarterbacks in this year‚Äôs postseason were selected in the first round. Three are no longer with the team that initially drafted them, a reminder of success teams have had in recent years finding quarterbacks via trade or free agency.

That history may be a tell for the Browns brass‚Äôs next move. And it may be a tell of Sanders‚Äô chance at keeping his starting job through 2026. Fifth-round quarterbacks face uphill battles. So do quarterbacks selected before a coach had input in that decision.

‚ÄúI think overall, like as a quarterback, I showed different pieces in different games to all add up to one complete quarterback,‚Äù Sanders said. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs what I had to get to in those situations ‚Äî red-zone situations, field-goal situations, third-down situations, ‚Äòwhere you at on the field‚Äô situations. So, it was a lot of situations that was good. I feel like this was a good learning year for me, and I‚Äôm excited for it. Because like I say, like moving forward I‚Äôll be prepared.

‚ÄúI did what I was able to do, and I definitely grew from a lot of things. And I got experience now. So, I‚Äôm always the same: confidence-wise, I‚Äôm there. But like, that‚Äôs not in my hands. Like, that‚Äôs not my decision.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt speak on what other people feel.‚Äù

fullText:
