title: Is there a secret to playing college sports? This boys coach says yes
description: Linda Martindale, a boys high school coach, mental fitness expert and mom to collegiate players, says college athletes have this special ingredient.
fullText:
Linda Martindale wasn‚Äôt brave, at least she didn‚Äôt think she was after she had been hired as a varsity boys basketball coach.

‚ÄúOnce the game started, I was fine,‚Äù says Martindale, now in her sixth season leading Lincoln-Sudbury (MA), ‚Äúbut walking into the gym and people thinking I'm the scorekeeper or whatever, I had to sort of overcome this feeling of, ‚ÄòDo I belong in the gym?‚Äô ‚Äù

She made the three words her mantra, and she convinced herself she was brave. You need to be as an athlete, or a coach, in today‚Äôs world of youth sports.

‚ÄúI have fond memories of my athletic career, but I also know there was a lot of heartache and it was very difficult,‚Äù says Martindale, who played Division II basketball at Alaska-Anchorage and in the old Pac-10 at Arizona in the late 1980s and early 1990s. ‚ÄúBut nowadays, it's totally different. Your whole career is splashed all over social media.‚Äù

Martindale‚Äôs father devoted his life to coaching baseball and football, driving her and her three siblings to be punctual and polite. He was hard on them, she says, but led with love.

‚ÄúIf I had a bad game, the people in the stands knew and my parents knew, and that was it,‚Äù Martindale tells USA TODAY Sports. ‚ÄúYou'd come home and your parents would say, ‚ÄòHow did the game go?' You could self-report that. Easy to deal with.

‚ÄúMy oldest son would literally get DMs from strangers that say horrible things if he missed a free throw in the clutch. The landscape is very different. And it obviously trickles down to youth.‚Äù

Martindale got certified as a mental fitness coach to help ease the pressure on her three sons and one daughter (all of them have played college sports) but also other young athletes.

She works with sports teams at Division I Holy Cross and D-III Curry College, as well as individual athletes. She says there‚Äôs a secret beyond the physical component to playing sports in college.

We offer 10 ways, through consultation with Martindale, for parents to help athletes get there.

YOUTH SPORTS SURVIVAL GUIDE:¬†Pre-order Coach Steve's upcoming book for young athletes and their parents

When Martindale walked into the gym feeling the male eyes on her, she felt she needed an inner coach.

Your coach on the court or field will tell you what to do but, Martindale says, the one in your head will kick you in the butt to help get you where you need to go.

Jenny Levy, who has won four national titles as North Carolina‚Äôs women‚Äôs lacrosse coach, believes so strongly in an inner coach she likes when her players form their own mantras.

‚ÄúConfidence looks good on you,‚Äù she heard her players say to each other in 2013, the year they broke through.

‚ÄúA lot of coaches will say, ‚ÄòThis is our saying,‚Äô ‚Äù Levy told Martindale on Martindale‚Äôs ‚ÄòGame Changers‚Äô podcast. ‚ÄúAnd I think that‚Äôs fine ‚Äì to each his own ‚Äì but I actually let our team organically come up with their own little things. This is the team having a good time together.‚Äù

The inner voice tells you it doesn‚Äôt matter what anyone else thinks, only what you do.

To come up with your own mantra, Martindale says, ask yourself why you play a sport? Look for performance cues to grind that thought into you.

‚ÄúIt's not fun to lose, but it's still really fun to compete and to play,‚Äù Martindale says. ‚ÄúOK, good, let's start with that. So at least you can say it's not fun to lose, but it's really fun to prepare for the game. We've now established that the majority of the time is fun. Now we can get through the parts that aren't fun.‚Äù

Was that ‚Äòfun‚Äô? How Coco Gauff‚Äôs tough US Open embodies what the word means

Kids respond to the truth. We don‚Äôt need to always sugarcoat it.

Instead of saying, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not so hard,‚Äù acknowledge that something is.

Maybe you‚Äôre afraid that you might lose or you‚Äôre going to make a fool of yourself in front of everybody.

‚ÄúI'm happy that you can articulate a fear,‚Äù Martindale might tell an athlete. ‚ÄúNow, let's squash it. What are you really afraid of? Is it really embarrassing to lose, or is it embarrassing not to play at all?

‚ÄúIt would be embarrassing if you threw yourself on the floor and screamed and cried in the middle of the game. But nobody thinks it's embarrassing that you sat on the bench, cheered on your team, and then fought another day to try to get some minutes.‚Äù

A current role doesn‚Äôt mean an ultimate role. Martindale goes back to Tom Brady.

He was once buried deep on Michigan‚Äôs depth chart. But he focused on nailing reps he got in practice. He was at game speed when he found himself starting.

‚ÄúAs parents, we say, ‚ÄòI don't think you should have to be the backup quarterback,' " Martindale says. ‚Äú 'I think you should be the quarterback.‚Äô This is not helping. What you need to do is crush being the backup. And then your time comes and you're ready instead of spending so much time worrying that you don't have the role that you want (and) you're not ready for it.‚Äù

Another of her podcast guests, Luke Avdalovic, a former walk-on basketball player at Northern Arizona University, told her: ‚ÄúI had a teammate named JoJo Anderson and he told me, ‚ÄòIf you want to find a role into this team, find one thing that you‚Äôre really good at. Make sure you‚Äôre head and shoulders better than every single other person on the team. Then they can‚Äôt take you off the floor.‚Äô ‚Äù

Avdalovic became a top sharpshooter who rose to the NBA G-League.

Avdalovic has shot so much over the years he feels he‚Äôs never really in a slump. Some days he shoots better than others, but that is just the law of averages.

‚ÄúYou can't be a pitcher if you can't pitch poorly,‚Äù Martindale says. ‚ÄúYou can't be a shooter if you can't miss. It's just not possible (to) be perfect. So what do you do when you're imperfect?‚Äù

The next time your son or daughter has a bad game, ask them, ‚ÄúDid you compete hard?‚Äù

You don‚Äôt want them to lose or fail but they need to know how to do both. As parents, and as coaches, our best support can come out of struggles.

You know the term if you‚Äôre a baseball fan. Suddenly, Steve Sax or Chuck Knoblauch can‚Äôt make a routine throw from second to first base, or Rick Ankiel can‚Äôt throw a strike.

‚ÄúYips is not a real thing,‚Äù Martindale says.

Struggles come alive, she says, when we say them out loud. Instead, if you‚Äôre a parent or a coach, tell your athlete: ‚ÄúI really believe in you. Just keep throwing, you'll get it back, you'll find a rhythm.‚Äù

When kids feel deep-rooted support, they have more confidence in themselves.

Martindale says today‚Äôs world for young athletes is like taking the SATs while your score is being put on a scoreboard.

Sometimes, it seems, we expect our kids to be good at everything. Martindale asks the ones with whom she works, ‚ÄúWhat class are you good at?‚Äù

She doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean classes in which they have an ‚ÄúA,‚Äù but the ones they enjoy most.

Sometimes it takes looking at things through a less critical lens. We have an ‚ÄúA‚Äù in science, but we enjoy the challenge of English Lit, in which we have a B-, which energizes us to try and bring up the grade.

Eugene Glisky, Martindale‚Äôs father, had his ashes buried on the field where he coached near Toronto. She suspects he changed the lives of many young men.

But she stops short of calling a team a family.

‚ÄúWhen a coach says to a parent, ‚ÄòI'm gonna treat your son or daughter like my own,' I want to say, ‚ÄòNo, thank you. I don't need you to treat my son like he‚Äôs your own,‚Äô ‚Äù Martindale says. ‚ÄúHe has a great father. What I really want you to do is treat him like a player and a human being.

‚ÄúIt's a team, which is amazing and I love my kid being part of a team. But it's not a family. Why? Because what happens when your family cuts you?‚Äù

There are times when we need to be Coach, and times when we need to be Mom or Dad. Martindale had to be Coach when Judson, her oldest who now plays basketball for Manchester Basketball Club in the United Kingdom, came out of a game when he was younger and looked at her like, ‚ÄúWhy are you pulling me?

He threw his water bottle, and she turned and said: "You can take your sneakers off. You're done."

The same coach, though, drove him home from a different game, criticizing him for what he didn‚Äôt do while failing to realize he was sick.

"So many examples of total failure by me," she says. "What kind of mother would be talking to their kid about some offensive set when clearly they needed a mother?"

Levy, North Carolina‚Äôs women‚Äôs lacrosse coach, does parent Zoom calls. Before the first one, she asked her players what they wanted her to tell them.

‚ÄúThey said, ‚ÄòWe don‚Äôt want to talk about the game at the tailgate after,‚Äô ‚Äù Levy told Martindale. ‚Äú ‚ÄòWe don‚Äôt want any parent to have this sad conversation after the wins because their kid didn‚Äôt play. We want the parents to sit together. We want them to be positive on the sideline.‚Äô ‚Äù

Levy says the players gave her a Letterman top 10 of parent no-no‚Äôs, which she shared on the Zoom.

‚ÄúI think they were pretty shocked,‚Äù says Levy, who coaches her daughter, Kate, on the team. ‚ÄúOur kids were like, ‚ÄòLast year was not OK. This is what we want and this is what we need this year.‚Äô

‚ÄúAnd then if we saw it, I had permission from our players to call the parent and say, ‚ÄòHey, you‚Äôre at the tailgate and your behavior was below the line for our program.‚Äô

‚ÄúWhat if I acted like that as a parent? What if I did that in the middle of a tailgate?‚Äù

Levy‚Äôs point: A kid could be completely happy but if the parent is unhappy with their role, then the kid‚Äôs unhappy. And if the parent isn‚Äôt feeling like their kid is getting a fair shake, or they‚Äôre being really negative toward coaches or teammates, the kid internalizes the feeling.

‚ÄúYour influence is not neutral, parents,‚Äù Levy says.

During a clip Martindale shared of her speaking to athletes, she says, ‚ÄúThere has to be wins in there. Otherwise, you can't go an entire season and be like, ‚ÄòIf we don't win a game, this whole season is a waste.‚Äô ‚Äù

She is not necessarily talking about checks in the ‚ÄúW‚Äù column as much as what we perceive as personal wins. Maybe you tell a teammate you loved the way he blocked a punt or moved into position on defense. If we don‚Äôt have wins, even within losses, you don‚Äôt learn how to win.

Youth sports 'crisis':¬†Congress addresses big business in youth sports. Can we fix it?

Martindale believes there are five pillars of mental fitness: 1. Staying in the moment; 2. Controlling the controllables; 3. Seeing mistakes as opportunities; 4. Not judging yourself (or others) too harshly and 5. Comparison (positively).

She says she was once a failure at all of them. Has she since learned a special ingredient we need to have to play college sports?

Martindale thinks Angela Duckworth, director of the Penn-Wharton¬†Behavior Change for Good Initiative, said it best.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs grit,‚Äù Martindale has said. ‚ÄúI'm obsessed with grit, because we know it's a single defining characteristic of successful people.

‚ÄúCan you get up after you get knocked down? The athletes who are successful at every level of college, I think, have this kind of dog mentality that is about grit. And of course, you have to be skilled and you have to be athletic but when we really look at who performs best when it counts, it's people who have failed. Over and over and over. And then now they succeed.‚Äù

We can‚Äôt beat our kids up over mistakes. Let them hear the voice in their head that gives them the grace to move forward from them.

Then, as Martindale says: ‚ÄúWatch them fail and then watch what they do after they fail.‚Äù

Borelli, aka Coach Steve,¬†has been an¬†editor and writer with USA TODAY since 1999. He spent 10 years coaching his two sons‚Äô baseball and basketball teams. He and his wife, Colleen, are now sports parents for two high schoolers. His Coach Steve column is posted weekly.¬†For his past columns, click here.

Got a question for Coach Steve you want answered in a column? Email him at¬†sborelli@usatoday.com

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Boys coach Linda Martindale has secret to being a college player

title: Girona-Atl√©tico: high-demand clash at Montilivi
description: Girona FC returns to Montilivi this Sunday, December 21, at 2:00 PM to face one of the most challenging opponents in the EA Sports League 2025-26, Atl√©tico de Madrid. The match comes at an intense mo...
fullText:
Girona FC returns to Montilivi this Sunday, December 21, at 2:00 PM to face one of the most challenging opponents in the EA Sports League 2025-26, Atl√©tico de Madrid. The match comes at an intense moment in the season, with both teams determined to earn valuable points towards their respective football goals.

Girona approaches this match after a very positive weekend, with a notable away victory against Real Sociedad (1-2), their first win of the season away from Montilivi. This triumph comes in a context where Girona has competed with determination in recent league matches, also achieving notable draws such as the 1-1 against Real Madrid and the 1-1 against Betis.

Meanwhile, Atl√©tico de Madrid arrives at Montilivi with a solid trajectory in the league despite some recent difficulties. In the previous matchday, the team led by Diego Simeone returned to winning ways with a 2-1 victory over Valencia, with goals from Antoine Griezmann and Koke, regaining confidence after some matchdays with irregular results. This triumph has boosted the team's confidence and helped them remain among the top teams in the LaLiga standings. The Madrid team has also competed internationally, achieving an important result for their European aspirations in the Champions League group stage by winning 2-3 away against PSV.

Among the most memorable matches is a thrilling 4-3 victory by Girona against Atl√©tico played at Montilivi in January 2024, a duel with goal alternations and intensity, in which the Girona team delivered a memorable offensive performance. On the other hand, in the 2024-25 season, the home match ended with an adverse result (0-4) against Atl√©tico on matchday 38 of the league, a game where the Madrid team showed great offensive effectiveness.

Another recent example was at the beginning of that same season, when Girona visited the Metropolitano and, despite competing, ended with a 3-0 defeat against the Madrid team.

The Girona fans will have a date with high-level football at home this Sunday, with the team's commitment to compete intensely from the first minute. As the season progresses and with every point at stake in LaLiga, this preview of the match against Atl√©tico de Madrid sets up a clash that promises excitement, strategy, and dedication from both squads, with Montilivi as the stage for the showdown.

title: 'Clown show': Anthony Joshua vs. Jake Paul ‚Äî sports world erupts after bizarre, brutal fight
description: Love him or hate him ‚Äî Jake Paul knows how to draw a reaction out of people. Friday's latest sideshow fight with Anthony Joshua was no exception.
fullText:
Love him or hate him ‚Äî Jake Paul knows how to draw a reaction out of people. Friday's latest sideshow fight was no different.

In a matchup that baffled the fight world, former two-time unified heavyweight boxing champion Anthony Joshua made easy work of Paul, dropping the YouTuber-turned-pugilist four times en route to a brutal sixth-round knockout live on Netflix. Joshua was an overwhelming BetMGM favorite coming into the weekend for good reason ‚Äî the Englishman, who stands 6-foot-6 with a monstrous 82-inch reach, towered over Paul in both stature and r√©sum√©, and he put those advantages to good use.

After a slow start, Joshua battered Paul around the ring in a bizarre and lopsided fight that saw Paul repeatedly dive for Joshua's legs as if he was shooting an MMA-style double-leg takedown. Paul said afterward that he believed he suffered a broken jaw due to Joshua's powerful punches.

Not surprisingly, given how high-profile Paul's fights have become, the sports world had plenty to say about six rounds it witnessed Friday. Check out some of the reaction to Joshua vs. Paul below.

title: Broadcast schedule for 2026 Indy NXT season announced by FOX Sports, IndyCar
description: All 17 rounds of IndyCar's developmental championship will be shown on live television for the second consecutive year.
fullText:
FOX Sports and IndyCar have confirmed the race broadcast start times of the 2026 season for Indy NXT.

For the second consecutive year, the developmental category for the IndyCar Series will have all 17 rounds shown on live television, with 15 scheduled for FS1 and two on FS2. All practice and qualifying sessions will be shown on a combination of FS1, FS2, the FOX Sports App and FOX One.

‚ÄúOur immersive partnership with FOX Sports has fueled impressive gains across our ecosystem, most especially within Indy NXT by Firestone,‚Äù Penske Entertainment Corp. President and CEO Mark Miles said.

‚ÄúIn 2026, we expect that significant growth to continue with additional races providing even more intense on-track action for our development series. The competition will be fierce for the drivers vying to advance to the NTT IndyCar Series, and FOX Sports‚Äô coverage will provide another remarkable showcase.‚Äù

Chip Ganassi Racing completes four-car roster for 2026 Indy NXT season

The road to the 2026 championship begins at 10 a.m. (all times Eastern) Sunday, March 1 on FS1 on the Streets of St. Petersburg.

One of the most anticipated rounds takes place two weeks later with the inaugural Streets of Arlington, with the race on the 14-turn, 2.73-mile temporary circuit beginning at 11 a.m. Sunday, March 15 on FS1.

The summer stretch of races at Road America, Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course and Nashville Superspeedway will coincide with FOX Sports‚Äô expansive coverage of the 2026 FIFA World Cup.

The doubleheader in Elkhart Lake, Wisconsin, will take place at 12:30 p.m. Saturday, June 20 at and at noon Sunday, June 21, with both races airing on FS1. Coverage at Mid-Ohio‚Äôs doubleheader begins at 1 p.m. Saturday, July 4 and at 10 a.m. Sunday, July 5, with both races scheduled to air on FS1.

The television tune-in time for the Indy NXT race at Nashville will be announced in the coming weeks.

The championship concludes with the final doubleheader of the year at Laguna Seca with a race at 6:30 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 5 on FS2, followed by the season finale and the crowning of the Indy NXT champion at 12:30 p.m. Sunday, Sept. 6 on FS1. It is the 15th time in series history that the legendary and historic track on California‚Äôs central coast will play host to the title celebration.

Indianapolis Motor Speedway Road Course Race 1

Indianapolis Motor Speedway Road Course Race 2

Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course Race 1

Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course Race 2

WeatherTech Raceway Laguna Seca Race 1

WeatherTech Raceway Laguna Seca Race 2

To read more Motorsport.com articles visit our website.

title: TNT Sports replaces BBC as Commonwealths live broadcaster
description: The subscription channel takes over from the BBC which had been the principal partner since 1954 and provided free-to-air coverage.
fullText:
The BBC has been replaced by TNT Sports as live UK broadcast partner for the Glasgow 2026 Commonwealth Games.

The subscription channel outbid the BBC, which had been the main partner and provided free-to-air coverage since 1954 for 18 games in a row.

TNT Sports is part of Warner Bros Discovery and is best known for screening Uefa Champions League matches as well as selected English Premier League fixtures.

The BBC said it was "unable to match" TNT's bid to screen the games, which will take place from 23 July to 2 August.

title: Celebrate local sports heroes at Wisconsin Rapids awards Jan. 14
description: Celebrate local sports leaders at the 2025 Wisconsin Rapids Area Sports Commission awards Jan. 14. Tickets support local sports initiatives. Reserve by Jan. 2!
fullText:
WISCONSIN RAPIDS ‚àí The Wisconsin Rapids Area Sports Commission has announced the nominees for the 2025 Wisconsin Rapids Area Sports Awards Celebration, according to a community announcement.

The event is scheduled for 5 p.m. Jan. 14 at Bullseye Country Club. It recognizes individuals who have shown commitment, leadership and impact in the local sports community and sports tourism industry.

The event includes three awards: Rookie of the Year, MVP and Lifetime Achievement. The Rookie of the Year Award honors emerging leaders in their first one to two years of involvement. The MVP Award recognizes individuals with at least three years of exceptional leadership and contribution. The Lifetime Achievement Award celebrates those with more than 20 years of impact on the local sports industry and includes induction into the WRASC Hall of Fame.

This year‚Äôs nominees are Ken Hilgers, Phil Jagielo, Klaus Kroner, Wesley Kurzewski, Eric Mellot, Dave Michels and Brian Wendt.

The awards celebration is open to the public. Tickets are $15 in advance or $25 at the door and include a light buffet, networking and cash bar. All proceeds support the WRASC's initiatives.

To reserve a spot, email cvbstaff@visitwisrapids.com or call 715-422-4650 by Jan. 2.

This story was created by reporter Nida Tazeen, NTazeen@usatodayco.com, with the assistance of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Journalists were involved in every step of the information gathering, review, editing and publishing process. Learn more at cm.usatoday.com/ethical-conduct.‚Äã

This article originally appeared on Wisconsin Rapids Daily Tribune: Wisconsin Rapids sports awards honor leaders and legends Jan. 14

title: Lots more to achieve after incredible year - McIlroy
description: Newly crowned Sports Personality of the Year winner Rory McIlroy says he has "a lot more I want to achieve" after an "incredible" 2025.
fullText:
Newly crowned Sports Personality of the Year winner Rory McIlroy says he has "a lot more I want to achieve" after an "incredible" 2025.

Northern Ireland's McIlroy became just the sixth man to complete the career Grand Slam of all four majors when he won the Masters in a thrilling finish in April.

The 36-year-old then played a pivotal role in Europe's Ryder Cup win in September, contributing three-and-a-half points as they sealed a first victory in the USA since 2012.

"I don't know what I'm going to do in 2026 to top it but I'm going to try," McIlroy told BBC Sport NI.

"I've got a nice little bit of time off over Christmas and New Year and I think that's the time to maybe put the highlights on and watch it back and reflect.

"It's been an incredible 12 months and I want to enjoy everything that I've done, but at the same time, this isn't it for me - I have got a lot more I want to achieve."

title: üö®Dimayor releases the official fixture for Liga BetPlay I
description: The Sports Management of the Divisi√≥n Mayor del F√∫tbol Colombiano (DIMAYOR) has taken the first official step toward the new season by announcing the fixture for the 19 matchdays of the Liga BetPlay...
fullText:
The Sports Management of the Divisi√≥n Mayor del F√∫tbol Colombiano (DIMAYOR) has taken the first official step toward the new season by announcing the fixture for the 19 matchdays of the Liga BetPlay DIMAYOR I-2026. With this announcement, the country‚Äôs professional clubs now know the order of their matchups for the tournament that will kick off the football year.

One of the most relevant pieces of news for fans is the confirmation of the competition format. After various deliberations regarding the tournament‚Äôs structure, it has been decided that the league for the first half of the year will return to a direct elimination system.

The championship will be divided into three clear stages:

All-Against-All Phase: Played over 19 matchdays.

Playoff Phase: The top-ranked teams will face each other in direct elimination brackets.

Grand Final: The title will be decided in home-and-away matches.

Read the full fixture by clicking here.

DIMAYOR clarified that the calendar was created using specialized software that had already been used for managing the second half of 2025, aiming to ensure fairness in rest periods and travel logistics.

Although the order of the matches is already set, the exact dates and times for the first 18 matchdays will be announced in a later statement. This early planning aims to allow teams to organize their preseason preparations more rigorously for a 2026 that promises to be highly competitive.

title: Southport girls' fathers win Helen Rollason Award
description: Sergio Aguiar and David Stancombe, the fathers of two of the young girls killed in Southport last year, receive the Helen Rollason Award at BBC Sports Personality of the Year 2025.
fullText:
Sergio Aguiar and David Stancombe, the fathers of two of the young girls killed in Southport last year, were presented with the Helen Rollason Award at BBC Sports Personality of the Year 2025.

Elsie Dot Stancombe, Alice da Silva Aguiar and Bebe King died at a Taylor Swift-themed dance workshop in July 2024.

Since that day, the three families have set out to establish lasting legacies in their daughters' names through the projects Elsie's Story, Alice's WonderDance and Bebe's Hive.

Alice's father Sergio and Elsie's dad David ran the 2025 London Marathon.

Sergio raised funds to build a new playground at Churchtown Primary School, where Alice and Bebe were pupils, while David ran for Elsie's Story.

They were presented with their award by former Liverpool striker Robbie Fowler and comedian John Bishop.

"I'm very grateful to accept the award tonight but I'm just a dad keeping a promise to his little girl," David said.

"Elsie wanted me to run the London Marathon and I did. It gave me a massive focus through the hardest time I've ever lived through."

Sergio added: "I want to dedicate this award to our three girls: Alice, Elsie and Bebe. Keep dancing.

"I want to spread Alice's magic across the world. I am going to keep running and raising money for her foundation."

The Helen Rollason Award recognises outstanding achievement in the face of adversity.

It was introduced to Sports Personality of the Year in 1999 in memory of the BBC Sport journalist and presenter, who died of cancer that year aged 43.

title: Remembering the sports stars we lost in 2025
description: A host of figures from the world of sport died in 2025 - BBC Sport remembers some of those sporting names.
fullText:
A host of figures from the world of sport died in 2025.

Here, we remember some of those sporting names.

Tiger Bech, external: The 27-year-old All-Ivy League kick returner for Princeton was among those killed in a vehicle attack in New Orleans.

Tony Blanco: Former Washington Nationals player was one of the 231 people killed when a roof collapsed at a nightclub in the Dominican Republic.

Ethan Dietz: Junior college basketball player died after sustaining an injury during a game in Texas. He played for Connors State College in Warner, Oklahoma.

Octavio Dotel: Former MLB pitcher won the 2011 World Series with the St Louis Cardinals. Died when the roof collapsed at a nightclub in the Dominican Republic.

Virginia Halas McCaskey:, external The only daughter of Pro Football Hall of Famer George Halas had been the Chicago Bears' principal owner since 1983.

Jim Irsay:, external Owner of the Indianapolis Colts.

Arthur Jones:, external Played for Baltimore Ravens, Indianapolis Colts and Washington Redskins and was a Super Bowl winner in 2013.

Marshawn Kneeland: Played for the Dallas Cowboys this season.

D. D. Lewis:, external American Hall of Fame football player was a Super Bowl champion with the Dallas Cowboys in 1972 and 1978.

Nick Mangold:, external Played in the Pro Bowl seven times during a decorated career with the New York Jets.

Doug Martin: Former American football player for Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Oakland Raiders.

Steve McMichael:, external American Hall of Fame football player won the Super Bowl with the Chicago Bears. He was also a WCW wrestler.

Dave Parker:, external American Hall of Fame baseball player (Cincinnati Reds, Pittsburgh Pirates, Oakland Athletics) won the World Series in 1979 and 1989.

Bobby Rousseau:, external Canadian ice hockey player was a four-time Stanley Cup champion and claimed Olympic silver in 1960.

Ryne Sandberg:, external American Hall of Fame baseball player for the Chicago Cubs and manager with the Philadelphia Phillies.

Lenny Wilkens:, external He was inducted three times into the Basketball Hall of Fame, first in 1989 as a player, as a coach in 1998, and in 2010 as part of the 1992 United States Olympic 'Dream Team' as assistant coach.

Shewarge Alene:, external The 2025 Stockholm Marathon winner died after collapsing during a training session.

Menzies 'Ming' Campbell: 'The Flying Scotsman' represented Great Britain at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics. He set a new British 100m record of 10.2 seconds in 1967, beating a young OJ Simpson in the process. Went on to become an MP and led the Liberal Democrats from 2006 to 2007.

Terence Higgins:, external Represented Great Britain at the 1948 and 1952 Olympics and won a silver medal at the 1950 British Empire Games in New Zealand in the 4x400m relay.

Thelma Hopkins: Northern Irish high jumper won Olympic silver in 1956.

Maeve Kyle: Irish hockey international also represented Ireland in three Olympic Games in athletics and was the first Irish female track and field Olympian, competing in the 100m and 200m.

Alf Meakin: The sprinter was part of the 4x100m British relay team known as the 'Flying Squad', who won gold at the 1962 Perth Commonwealth Games and bronze at the Belgrade European Championships. He also competed at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics.

John Sherwood:, external The 1968 Olympic 400m hurdles bronze medallist also competed at the Munich Games in 1972. He was a European silver medallist the following year and won Commonwealth Games gold in Edinburgh in 1970.

Fauja Singh: British-Indian man, who was believed to be the world's oldest marathon runner, died after being hit by a car in India at the age of 114. He began running at 89 and ran nine full marathons between 2000 and 2013.

Lachie Stewart: Inductee in the Scottish Sports Hall of Fame, who competed for Great Britain in the 10,000m at the 1972 Olympics and also won Commonwealth Games gold.

Gordon Wright:, external A senior figure in British Athletics for more than six decades and served as England's team manager at two Commonwealth Games. He was also team manager of Great Britain's men's athletics.

Tony Jordan, external: Englishman won European mixed doubles gold and Commonwealth silver.

Gordon Cook: Represented England and Great Britain in the 1950s and 60s and won numerous national men's titles with London Central YMCA.

John Russell Evans:, external Four-time Welsh champion.

Peter Line:, external English lawn bowler was world outdoor champion in 1972.

Rahaman Ali:, external The younger brother of Muhammad Ali, who was also a professional boxer.

Nino Benvenuti:, external Italian former undisputed super-welterweight and middleweight world champion. Won Olympic gold in 1960 and had an amateur record of 120-0.

Tommy Brooks:, external American boxing trainer for the likes of Evander Holyfield and Mike Tyson.

Joe Bugner: Won British and Commonwealth heavyweight titles and was a three-time European heavyweight champion. He faced Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier in back-to-back bouts in 1973, before facing Ali again - for the world title - in 1975.

James Cook:, external Former European and British super-middleweight boxing champion was awarded an MBE for services to young people and charities.

John Cooney: Irish boxer died following injuries sustained defending his Celtic super-featherweight title.

Don Elbaum:, external American Hall of Fame boxing promoter and manager.

George Foreman: Iconic two-time world heavyweight champion and 1968 Olympic champion.

George Gilbody:, external Fought for Great Britain at the 1980 Olympics at lightweight.

Ricky Hatton: Former light-welterweight and welterweight world champion was one of the most popular boxers Great Britain has ever produced.

Greg Haugen:, external American boxer was a former IBF lightweight and WBO light-welterweight champion.

Mark Kaylor:, external Reached the middleweight quarter-finals for Great Britain at the 1980 Moscow Olympics.

Mike McCallum:, external Jamaican boxer was a world champion at light-middleweight, middleweight and light-heavyweight.

Dick McTaggart: The only Scotsman to win an Olympic boxing gold with his success at lightweight at the 1956 Games. He added a bronze at the Rome Olympics in 1960 and finished his amateur career with 610 wins from 634 contests.

Georgia O'Connor: 2017 Commonwealth Youth Games champion had podium finishes at both the Youth World and European Championships.

Robert Wells:, external 1984 Olympic bronze medallist for Great Britain.

Boris Spassky:, external World champion took part in the famous 'Match of the Century' against American Bobby Fischer in 1972.

Jon Atkinson:, external Played for Somerset and Cambridge University.

Dickie Bird: Became a legendary cricket umpire after a playing career at both Yorkshire and Leicestershire.

Michael Boyers:, external Played one first-class game for Essex.

Robert Brooke:, external Renowned cricket writer and statistician.

David Bulfield:, external Played Minor Counties cricket for Dorset.

Peter Close:, external Represented Cambridge University and Dorset.

Christopher Chaplin:, external Played Minor Counties cricket for Cornwall.

Bob Cowper:, external Played 27 Tests for Australia and was the first Australian batter to score a triple-century against England in Australia in 1966.

Giles Daniels: Former Gloucestershire player.

Andy Dindar:, external South African-born English cricketer represented the likes of Gloucestershire, Hertfordshire and Berkshire.

Patrick Dineen, external: Played 23 times for Ireland.

Dilip Doshi:, external Spinner played 33 Tests for India and had stints in county cricket with Nottinghamshire and Warwickshire.

Peter Eyre:, external Played first-class cricket for Derbyshire.

Jeff Evans:, external Welsh cricket umpire stood in more than 200 first-class and List A matches.

Neil French: Played Minor Counties cricket for Lincolnshire.

Nick Gandon:, external English cricketer for the likes of Hertfordshire, Lincolnshire and Oxford University.

Alan Hobbs:, external Represented Cambridgeshire in Minor Counties cricket.

Mike 'Pasty' Harris:, external Batter scored more than 20,000 runs for Nottinghamshire and also played for Middlesex.

David Hays:, external Batter and wicketkeeper played 25 times for Scotland and also represented Cambridge University.

David Hughes:, external All-rounder played for Somerset and Wiltshire.

John Jameson:, external Won the County Championship with Warwickshire and played four times for England.

Harry Kelleher:, external Fast bowler played for Surrey and Northamptonshire.

Barry Knight:, external Played 29 Tests for England and represented Essex and Leicestershire.

Wayne Larkins: English batter won 13 Test caps and played 25 one-day internationals. Played for Northamptonshire.

David Lawrence: Played for Gloucestershire and became the first British-born black player to represent England, winning five Test caps.

Peter Lever: Fast bowler played 17 times for England as well as playing for Lancashire.

Peter Ledden:, external Former cricketer for Sussex.

Robin Matthews: , externalBowler played for Leicestershire and Oxfordshire.

Gavin McKiddie, external: Bowler made one appearance for Scotland.

Martin Olley:, external Batter played for the likes of Northamptonshire, Middlesex and Cambridgeshire.

Babu Meman:, external Zimbabwe international also played for Shropshire.

Michael Reith:, external Played nine times for Ireland.

Ken Shuttleworth:, external Won five Test caps for England and played for Lancashire and Leicestershire.

Bob Simpson:, external Played 62 Tests for Australia and captained the side. Later took over as Australia coach and oversaw one of the greatest teams in cricket history.

Robin Smith: Nicknamed 'Judge', Smith won 62 England Test caps between 1988 and 1996 and scored 4,236 runs at an average 43.67, including nine centuries. He spent his entire county career at Hampshire, winning two Benson & Hedges Cups and a NatWest Trophy.

Peter Doyle:, external Irishman competed at the 1968 and 1972 Olympics in the road race.

Barry Hoban: Former record holder for the most Tour de France stage wins by a British rider having claimed eight between 1967 and 1975. He was also the first Briton to win two consecutive stages of the Tour, a feat matched by Sir Mark Cavendish and Geraint Thomas.

Samuele Privitera: Italian junior cyclist died aged 19 after a fall during the opening stage of the Giro della Valle d'Aosta.

Jamie Harvey:, external Known as 'Bravedart', the Scotsman played in every PDC World Championship between 1994 and 2006, reaching the semi-finals in 1996.

Loveday King:, external She won the BDO Gold Cup in 1981.

Lord Patrick Thomas Conolly-Carew:, external Represented Ireland in eventing at the 1968 and 1972 Olympics and was in the Irish team that won silver at the 1962 European Championships.

Peter Easterby: Three-time champion jumps trainer, won the Champion Hurdle on five occasions and the Cheltenham Gold Cup twice. He was the first British trainer to have more than 1,000 winners on both the flat and over the jumps.

Tricia Gardiner:, external Competed at the 1988 Olympics in dressage. Later became a highly respected mentor and judge.

Stan Hayhurst:, external Cheltenham Gold Cup-winning jockey aboard Kerstin - one of only four mares to win the Gold Cup - in 1958.

Barry Hills: British thoroughbred horse trainer had 3,181 winners in Britain and won four of the five British Classics at least once.

Tommie Jakes: Apprentice jockey rode 59 winners over the past three years on the flat in Britain.

Fulke Johnson Houghton:, external Legendary trainer led out more than 1,200 winners in his career.

Jane Kidd:, external Dressage competitor became a highly-respected judge, mentor and administrator within the sport. She edited British Dressage Magazine for 15 years.

Domini Lawrence:, external Competed at the Olympics in 1968 and 1972 in dressage and won the Horse of the Year dressage title for five consecutive years. She later became a top-level judge and was Great Britain's oldest surviving Olympian.

Geoff Lewis: Became the first Welsh jockey to win the Derby when he partnered the legendary Mill Reef to victory in 1971. Also enjoyed victories in the likes of the 1,000 and 2,000 Guineas, the Oaks, Coronation Cup, and Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe.

D Wayne Lukas:, external American horse trainer and US Racing Hall of Fame inductee. He won 20 Breeders' Cup races, 15 Triple Crown races and received five Eclipse Awards for his accomplishments

Edward O'Grady: Four-time champion in Ireland sent out more than 1,700 winners and enjoyed huge success at Cheltenham.

Michael O'Sullivan: Irish jockey died after a fall during a race in Thurles. Won the Supreme Novices' Hurdle on the opening day of the Cheltenham Festival. He rode 95 career winners.

Sir Thomas Pilkington:, external A successful owner, breeder and administrator, he was senior steward of the Jockey Club from 1994 to 1998 and also acted as chair of the British Horseracing Board.

Kevin Prendergast:, external Trainer won the 2000 Guineas and the Irish equivalent twice. He was British champion trainer in 1963 and sent out his 2,000th career winner in 2010.

Brian Rouse:, external Won the 1,000 Guineas on Quick As Lightning in 1980.

Joe Saumarez Smith: Served as chairman of the British Horseracing Authority.

William Sheret:, external Scotsman won the Daily Express Foxhunter Championship at the Horse of the Year Show in 1975.

Christopher Taylor:, external The racehorse trainer was also a horse stuntman on films. He later became a mentor to the likes of Jenny Pitman and dressage Olympian Carl Hester.

Sarah Yorke: Rider died from traumatic injuries after falling at the Aston-le-Walls Horse Trials in Northamptonshire.

Felix Baumgartner: Austrian broke a host of world records for extreme jumps. He famously set the record for the highest skydive by jumping from the edge of space from a height of 39km (24.2 miles) in the stratosphere back in 2012.

Ethan Ade-Oduwale:, external Played for Charlton Athletic's under-10s academy team.

Colin Addison: Played for Arsenal, Nottingham Forest and Sheffield United, and he was Hereford United's manager on their famous 1971-72 FA Cup run in which they upset Newcastle. He also led them into the Football League for the first time.

Bill Asprey:, external Played for Stoke City and Oldham Athletic, and also managed the Syrian national team.

Martin Bakes:, external The winger played for Bradford City and Scunthorpe United.

Chris Barnard:, external Former Wales Under-23 midfielder represented Torquay United, Ipswich Town and Southend United.

Chic Bates:, external Having played nearly 300 times for Shrewsbury Town, he guided them to their highest ever position of eighth in Division Two. Also managed Stoke City.

Matt Beard: Led Liverpool to back-to-back Women's Super League titles in 2013 and 2014 and returned for a second spell before leaving the club in February this year.

Tony Bedeau: Grenada international, who scored 65 goals in 374 appearances during two spells at Torquay.

Leo Beenhakker:, external Dutch football manager led Ajax and then won three La Liga titles with Real Madrid. He was in charge of the Netherlands at the 1990 World Cup, took Trinidad and Tobago to the 2006 World Cup and led Poland to Euro 2008.

David Best:, external Goalkeeper played for Bournemouth, Oldham, Ipswich and Portsmouth.

Stuart Boam: Former Middlesbrough captain made 320 appearances for the Teesside club and led them to the Second Division title. Also managed Mansfield Town.

Dennis Bond:, external Made 301 appearances in two stints with Watford and was part of the team which won promotion from the old Division Four under Graham Taylor in 1978. Also played for Charlton Athletic and Tottenham Hotspur.

Billy Bonds: West Ham's record appearance maker with 799 appearances and captained them to two FA Cup wins in 1975 and 1980. He spent 21 years as a player with the Hammers between 1967-1988 and also managed them from 1990 to 1994.

Jimmy Bone: Much-travelled striker and manager won two caps for Scotland. He helped Partick Thistle and Norwich win promotion to their respective top flights and was also part of the former's famous 4-1 Scottish League Cup final win over Celtic in 1971.

Geoff Foulds: , external Former player was the director and then chairman of the World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association.

Iris Cummings Critchell, external: She was the last living athlete from the Berlin 1936 Olympic Games. The American swimmer went on fly bombers as a pilot with the Women's Air Force in World War Two.

Warren Jacques:, external Australian was the first non-British captain of both the Great Britain Davis Cup and Federation Cup teams. As a player he reached the fourth round of Wimbledon.

Angela Mortimer Barrett: Her three Grand Slam singles titles came at Wimbledon in 1961, the 1955 French Championships and 1958 Australian Championships. She also won the women's doubles title at Wimbledon in 1955.

Nicola Pietrangeli: Italian won two singles titles at the French Championships and played in four finals at Roland Garros.

Fred Stolle: His two Grand Slam singles titles were won at the 1965 French Championships and the 1966 US Championships. Won 10 Grand Slam men's doubles titles, and seven Grand Slam mixed doubles titles.

Jack Ferguson: , external Competed at the Olympics in 1952 and 1956 and went on to coach the Great Britain team.

Dick Button:, external American figure skater won Olympic gold in 1948 and 1952 and claimed five straight World Championship titles. Later became an Emmy Award-winning broadcaster.

Laura Dahlmeier: Double Olympic biathlon champion died after a mountaineering accident in Pakistan. She was the first woman to win the sprint and pursuit events at the same Games and won a further 15 medals, including seven gold, across five World Championships.

Matteo Franzoso: Died after a training crash in Chile. Made his World Cup debut in December 2021 and his best performance was a 28th-place finish in the super-G at Cortina d'Ampezzo in 2023.

Lieutenant Colonel Sir Andrew Ogilvy-Wedderburn:, external Former British bobsleigh champion represented Team GB in the four-man event at the Winter Olympics in 1976 and 1980.

Evgenia Shishkova and Vadim Naumov: Two-time Olympians and former world figure skating champions were among the passengers killed in the Washington plane crash.

Roy Sinclair:, external He won curling silver at the Men's World Championship in 1976 before becoming a successful administrator, rising to be president of the World Curling Federation. Inducted into the World Curling Hall of Fame.

Buvaisar Saitiev:, external Russian won freestyle Olympic gold in 1996, 2004 and 2008 and was a six-time World Championship gold medallist.

title: 'This is your award, not mine' - Henry dedicates Lifetime Achievement to his children
description: Former Arsenal and France striker Thierry Henry is honoured with the Lifetime Achievement award at BBC Sports Personality of the Year 2025.
